member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine
member.summary: CalcEngine parses strings and returns Expression objects that can be evaluated.

remarks.para: This class has three extensibility points:
Use the DataContext property to add an object's properties to the engine scope.
Use the RegisterFunction method to define custom functions.
Override the GetExternalObject method to add arbitrary variables to the engine scope.

member.name: M:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Parses a string into an .
member.param: String to parse.
member.returns: An object that can be evaluated.

member.name: M:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.Evaluate(System.String)
member.summary: Evaluates a string.
member.param: Expression to evaluate.
member.remarks: If you are going to evaluate the same expression several times, it is more efficient to parse it only once using the method and then using the Expression.Evaluate method to evaluate the parsed expression.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.CacheExpressions
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the calc engine should keep a cache with parsed expressions.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.OptimizeExpressions
member.summary: Gets or sets whether the calc engine should optimize expressions when they are parsed.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.IdentifierChars
member.summary: Gets or sets a string that specifies special characters that are valid for identifiers.
member.remarks: Identifiers must start with a letter or an underscore, which may be followed by additional letters, underscores, or digits. This string allows you to specify additional valid characters such as ':' or '!' (used in Excel range references for example).

member.name: M:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.RegisterFunction(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32,ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngineFunction)
member.summary: Registers a function that can be evaluated by this .
member.param: Function name.
Minimum parameter count.
Maximum parameter count.
Delegate that evaluates the function.

member.name: M:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.RegisterFunction(System.String,System.Int32,ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngineFunction)
member.summary: Registers a function that can be evaluated by this .
member.param: Function name.
Parameter count.
Delegate that evaluates the function.

member.name: M:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.GetExternalObject(System.String)
member.summary: Gets an external object based on an identifier.
member.remarks: This method is useful when the engine needs to create objects dynamically. For example, a spreadsheet calc engine would use this method to dynamically create cell range objects based on identifiers that cannot be enumerated at design time (such as "AB12", "A1:AB12", etc.)

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.CalcEngine.DataContext
member.summary: Gets or sets the DataContext for this .
member.remarks: Once a DataContext is set, all public properties of the object become available to the CalcEngine, including sub-properties such as "Address.Street". These may be used with expressions just like any other constant.

member.summary: Get total count of cells in the specified range without initalizing them all (which might cause serious performance issues on column-wide calculations).

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.CellReferenceException
member.summary: This error occurs when you delete a cell referred to in the formula or if you paste cells over the ones referred to in the formula. Corresponds to the #REF! error in Excel

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.CellValueException
member.summary: This error is most often the result of specifying a mathematical operation with one or more cells that contain text. Corresponds to the #VALUE! error in Excel

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.DivisionByZeroException
member.summary: The division operation in your formula refers to a cell that contains the value 0 or is blank. Corresponds to the #DIV/0! error in Excel

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.NameNotRecognizedException
member.summary: This error value appears when you incorrectly type the range name, refer to a deleted range name, or forget to put quotation marks around a text string in a formula. Corresponds to the #NAME? error in Excel

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.NoValueAvailableException
member.summary: Technically, this is not an error value but a special value that you can manually enter into a cell to indicate that you donâ€™t yet have a necessary value. Corresponds to the #N/A error in Excel.

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.NullValueException
member.summary: Because a space indicates an intersection, this error will occur if you insert a space instead of a comma(the union operator) between ranges used in function arguments. Corresponds to the #NULL! error in Excel

member.name: T:ClosedXML.Excel.CalcEngine.Exceptions.NumberException
member.summary: This error can be caused by an invalid argument in an Excel function or a formula that produces a number too large or too small to be represented in the worksheet. Corresponds to the #NUM! error in Excel

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLCell.Value
member.summary:
Gets or sets the cell's value. To get or set a strongly typed value, use the GetValue<T> and SetValue methods.
ClosedXML will try to detect the data type through parsing. If it can't then the value will be left as a string.
If the object is an IEnumerable, ClosedXML will copy the collection's data into a table starting from this cell.
If the object is a range, ClosedXML will copy the range starting from this cell.
Setting the value to an object (not IEnumerable/range) will call the object's ToString() method.
member.value: The object containing the value(s) to set.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLCell.Address
member.summary: Gets this cell's address, relative to the worksheet.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLCell.CurrentRegion
member.summary: Returns the current region. The current region is a range bounded by any combination of blank rows and blank columns

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLCell.DataType
member.summary:
Gets or sets the type of this cell's data.
Changing the data type will cause ClosedXML to covert the current value to the new data type.
An exception will be thrown if the current value cannot be converted to the new data type.
member.value: The type of the cell's data.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.PageOrientation
member.summary: Gets or sets the page orientation for printing.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.PagesWide
member.summary:
Gets or sets the number of pages wide (horizontal) the worksheet will be printed on.
If you don't specify the PagesTall, Excel will adjust that value
based on the contents of the worksheet and the PagesWide number.
Setting this value will override the Scale value.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.PagesTall
member.summary:
Gets or sets the number of pages tall (vertical) the worksheet will be printed on.
If you don't specify the PagesWide, Excel will adjust that value
based on the contents of the worksheet and the PagesTall number.
Setting this value will override the Scale value.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.Scale
member.summary:
Gets or sets the scale at which the worksheet will be printed.
The worksheet will be printed on as many pages as necessary to print at the given scale.
Setting this value will override the PagesWide and PagesTall values.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.HorizontalDpi
member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal dpi for printing the worksheet.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.VerticalDpi
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical dpi for printing the worksheet.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.FirstPageNumber
member.summary:
Gets or sets the page number that will begin the printout.
For example, the first page of your printout could be numbered page 5.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.CenterHorizontally
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the worksheet will be centered on the page horizontally.
member.value: true if the worksheet will be centered on the page horizontally; otherwise, false.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.CenterVertically
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the worksheet will be centered on the page vertically.
member.value: true if the worksheet will be centered on the page vartically; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLPageSetup.AdjustTo(System.Int32)
member.summary:
Sets the scale at which the worksheet will be printed. This is equivalent to setting the Scale property.
The worksheet will be printed on as many pages as necessary to print at the given scale.
Setting this value will override the PagesWide and PagesTall values.
member.param: The scale at which the worksheet will be printed.

member.summary:

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLBaseCollection`2.Value
member.summary:
Sets the cells' value.
If the object is an IEnumerable ClosedXML will copy the collection's data into a table starting from each cell.
If the object is a range ClosedXML will copy the range starting from each cell.
Setting the value to an object (not IEnumerable/range) will call the object's ToString() method.
ClosedXML will try to translate it to the corresponding type, if it can't then the value will be left as a string.
member.value: The object containing the value(s) to set.

member.name: P:ClosedXML.Excel.IXLRanges.Value
member.summary:
Sets the cells' value.
If the object is an IEnumerable ClosedXML will copy the collection's data into a table starting from each cell.
If the object is a range ClosedXML will copy the range starting from each cell.
Setting the value to an object (not IEnumerable/range) will call the object's ToString() method.
ClosedXML will try to translate it to the corresponding type, if it can't then the value will be left as a string.
member.value: The object containing the value(s) to set.
